As a guy who has a "spider catching kit" (consisting of a plastic glass and a large index card) for capturing and removing arachnids and other bugs from the house — rather than squishing them — I can definitely relate to the personhood of dolphins.

(My grand daughter, who was taught to "hate" spiders, now tolerates them. When she wanted to know why I liberate them, I explained that they eat the things, like flies and mosquitoes, that eat her.)

All life is sacred, and one of our ongoing conflicts is that we have to kill something to live ourselves. One way to resolve the conflict is to eat low on the sentience ladder, but that doesn't quite resolve the whole issue. My own take, as someone who was raised as a sport hunter and quit forever at 19 because I could no longer see the point in harming innocent creatures, is that the ethicality of your actions is tied to your intention.

Do you kill for fun, or sport, or to establish your manhood? Or do you kill to eat or in true self defense. Do you respect what must be killed, and offset your killing by saving and sustaining life elsewhere? My wife and I grow a garden to reduce our ecological footprint but we also have a small "biodiversity garden," a pile of brush I maintain to house bugs or whatever grows there.

It's all a bit complex, but in the balance of things, it's quite clear that dolphins are about as high on the sentience scale as beings can get — maybe higher than we are.

Yes, everybody knows that high levels of oxygen cause retinopathy, and low levels increase mortality, but what's the right level?

If you think you know better than the doctors, what oxygen saturation would you give these infants? 85-89%? Or 91-95%?

I am a parent of 28 weeker twins. When I first walked into the NICU, my boys were hanging on to their life by a thread, my wife was in a painful post-surgery recovery, and I hadn't slept for 2 nights. If at that moment, a NICU doctor had thurst forward a research consent form that only mentioned risks from skin abrasions, I would have signed it. If it had mentioned blindness and death as risks, I would probably had paused even though death was licking its chops at that very moment. The latter information was clearly relevant and should have been mentioned, irrespective of how the study turned out. "Informed consent" requires information.

Mouse,

By your reasoning we should let nature take its course whenever there is a possibility of death for anyone, regardless of age--including you, for that matter, if the person ever has a potentially treatable but also potentially fatal disease.

Many of these babies die; many survive--some with disabilities and many more who do not have disabilities. What would you want the doctors and nurses to do? Withhold treatment altogether? Not even try because the chance of dying is greater than the chance of living overall? In other words kill off the babies who would have lived as well as those that would have died, simply because you don't want more disabled people in the world.

Just remember, we are all only an accident away from disability. You might feel differently about disability if it were you who became disabled.

They weren't put at risk. (Not by by the study. They were already at risk.)

You must give them some oxygen. You must not give them too much oxygen. The question is, how much? Some pediatricians were bringing the oxygen saturation up to 85-89%. Others were bringing it up to 91-95%. Whatever these parents did, whether they were in the study or not, their doctor would have given their child oxygen saturation somewhere in those ranges.

There were reasonable arguments for either range. But there wasn't good evidence. This study was trying to get good evidence. Now they know. They have better evidence that either range is reasonable, and they have a better idea of what the tradeoffs are between death, blindness and stroke.

No infant in this study was worse off than he or she would have been if they weren't in the study at all.

Without this study, they would have been treating patients without monitoring the results to see how effective their treatment was.

@rachel This parent is rightly disgusted that the child was exposed to increased risks through psychological coercion/manipulation and misleading consent forms. The whole point is that she'll never know whether her child's neurological impairments were due to the nature this research. Of course the researchers are to blame for misleading her.
Feel free to ignore Rachel Vassar. and blame whomever you like.  I hope your son does well in the future.   It took me years to get over the sound of those apnea alarms going off on my daughters.
Did they tell you at the end of the study which group your kid was in? Everything my child has been involved he was randomly selected and I did not find out which group he was in.

My nearly 4 yo was involved in this study-he was in the low oxygen group.  He lived, has sight but has significant neurological impairment.  We tried to beg off the study (the alarms associated with it were *extremely* grating) but each time a researcher reminded us of the importance of the data.  I feel kind of sick after reading this.

Not to mention these forms were given to new parents whose children were holding tenuously on to life.  Mom may still have been on pain meds from delivery, etc  In these instances especially researchers need take extra caution to get informed consent (not merely a signature).

I have been on IRB's and I would have asked why wasn't  blindness mentioned.  Now retrolental fibroplasia (I think it is now called blindness of prematurity) is not primarily caused by oxygen as was once thought, but it certainly is a factor.  You try to be totally honest with informed consent even if it means the study not being conducted.  The fact that it might frighten the parents is not a factor.  If a doctor gives you a drug don't you want to honestly know its potential side effects?
Blindness of prematurity (retrolental fibroblasia) is no longer thought to be primarily a consequence of high oxygen levels, but the oxygen levels do have an effect.

I think its a mistake to see these guys as buying support. Its more a marketplace where those who support powerful interests are the ones who are successful. The real vetting of candidates happens long before we see an advertisement on television or get to vote. There are numerous filters that prevent any who is unsympathetic to the interests of the rich and powerful from going very far in American politics.

While some politicians certainly trim their positions to win support of campaign contributors, that is a relatively minor part of the problem. If you are a dairy farmer you don't try to get milk from steers, you buy dairy cows. The same is true for powerful interests. They don't use their money to "bribe" politicians, they just make sure that most politicians who are successful are friendly to their interests.

What made him so insufferable was embodying many of the social conceits Americans rebelled against in 1776. His ineffectual attempts to mask it made him so disingenuously, cloyingly sanctimonious that he became as indigestible as treacle pudding.

Today's typical Red State Republican considers The Common Man an enemy, partly because he isn't white. The Republican Party is an unholy alliance founded on avarice and greed, a cabal of big corporations, enormous business interests and the wealthiest 1% against everybody else. That helps explain the death grip racists, bigots and assorted religious loonies have on the Party. The Party can't defend its Red State bastions without hordes of mountebanks and barbarians.

This is mostly self-important posturing by political pros. Their skills simply aren't that central to the results, no matter how many times they tell credulous reporters how they won/lost elections.

What really mattered was that the Republicans had an un-empathetic candidate that people did not trust to represent their interests. The Democrats had an empathetic candidate who had not been all that successful by most measures. They preferred someone they thought at least cared about helping them, rather than a candidate who didn't.

As for all the money spent. I suspect it was wasted because there were so many ads that they just drowned one another out. But the notion that better targeted ads were going to sell Romney as an empathetic candidate is the arrogant belief of people who think they are so good at their jobs that they can sell refrigerators to Eskimos. Eskimos are simply smarter than that.

It's fitting that the president is dedicating a bit of money to a brain mapping project right around this time. Hooray for science!

Exciting new technique but I doubt it's going to be much of a breakthrough in defining brain FUNCTION. It certainly will refine and deepen our understanding of brain STRUCTURE down to the cellular, even molecular, level. To a certain extent, function CAN BE DEDUCED based on structure. For example,this technique will allow us to visualize (in 3D) the complex dendritic arborizations and their connections (synapses) and may even allow us to detect the distribution of neurotransmitters and ion channels along the membrane of dendrites, axons, and nerve cell bodies. Based on these knowledge, we can then deduce how neurons, neuronal ensembles, and neural networks interact to produce certain types of brain function. But would that be enough to make us understand the physiological processes underlying sensory perception, memory, emotions, cognition, and other complex neural processes? I certainly doubt it. As a matter of fact, we already know a lot- not everything, but a lot - about neural architectonics and connectivity. We actually have many tools at our disposal for "imaging" the distribution of specific molecules such as transmitter receptors. For example, receptors can be targeted using ultraspecific monocloclonal antibodies or radiotracers and "imaged" using PET, optical imaging, etc. These "in-vivo" techniques are definitely more superior for studying brain function compared to the clarity method which can only be applied to dead brains.

Is this study about claiming victory? The Human brain is a complex marvel of nature. This is just one more step on a long journey of discovery. Kudos to the scientific efforts that were undertaken, progress in any form should be applauded!

page 2/2

The challenge in understanding brain function lies in the fact that for a certain function to take place multiple parts of the brain must be activated and work simultaneously within a small time window. A method with very high" temporal resolution" is the most ideal tool for studying brain function. To understand brain function, we have to know, not only how different parts of the network are interconnected; we must know the timing of activation of the structures involved in producing a specific function. And when we say function, we really mean "distributed processing" involving different neural networks. How can one figure that out by just looking at the structure of a dead piece of brain?

On the bright, if the clarity technique can show details of structure in 3D in a living brain and if this data can be COREGISTERED with another functional imaging technique, say PET, fMRI, or qEEG, while the subject is engaged in a specific function, then we may be able to elucidate the neural processes underlying such brain function. Only then can we claim victory!
Thanks to all members of the consortium for the great work!
